awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Lingyun Miao of University of Rochester to conduct a research project in Engineering during the summer of 2013 at Swinburne University of Technology in Melbourne. The project title is "Optical Delivery for Ultra-High Density Magnetic Hard Drives." The host scientist is Associate Professor Paul Stoddart.

Energy-assisted magnetic recording is one of the most promising future technologies for nano-scale magnetic recording. It requires the use of a focused laser beam to define magnetic recording feature, where high efficiency optical coupling and delivery of highly focused optical beam at low cost are key challenges. This research collaboration is designing nano-sized metallic structures that greatly reduce the spot size of incident optical beam. Properly engineered such structures can generate highly focused optical spot on the scale of tens of nanometers, which facilitates magnetic recording density beyond one terabyte per square inch.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Specifically, this project can not only advance the research of ultra-high density magnetic recording, but also benefit the relevant research societies due to its interdisciplinary nature.

por.por_cntn:
The hard disk drive (HDD) is the most commonly utilized non-volatile memory device that stores most of the world’s digital data, despite strong competition from solid-state drive (SSD). The biggest challenge for the HDD industry is that the conventional magnetic recording technology is about to reach its limit of recording density at 1 Tb/in^2. Energy-assisted magnetic recording (EAMR) is considered as one of the most flexible future techniques that can be implemented in the conventional HDD industry for extending recording density.

 

EAMR utilizes a highly focused laser beam to define magnetic recording features. As illustrated in the attached image, the recording density under the EAMR scheme is determined by the thermomagnetic recording mechanism. In general, a special recording medium which has good thermal stability at room temperature is used in EAMR. When a focused laser beam is delivered onto the medium surface, the local medium is temporarily heated up to exceed certain temperature to allow magnetic recording. When the local medium cools down to room temperature, it becomes stable again to retain data. Typically a laser power of about several tens of milliwatt is necessary to make this scheme work.

 

Based on the EAPSI 2013 summer work in Australia, the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award has designed a novel aluminum nano-sized structure and highly integrated micro-nano-optics system for use in EAMR. At an operating wavelength of 450 nm, the proposed aluminum structure can generate a 35 nm spot size inside the magnetic recording medium, corresponding to a recording density of up to 2 Tb/in^2. It also offers advantages of reduced cost and improved efficiency compared to traditional designs based on noble metals. The highly integrated micro-nano-optics design can ensure process compatibility and reliability of the aluminum structure. This work has demonstrated that aluminum can be a promising inexpensive material for the development of EAMR techniques, thereby providing a solution for the next generation of ultra-high density magnetic recording technique at or above 2 Tb/in^2. The results from this specific project can not only advance the research of ultra-high density magnetic recording, but also benefit the relevant research societies due to its interdisciplinary nature.
